title: Will the United States remove Iran from the list of countries identified as state sponsors of terrorism before 18 October 2016?
preds: Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

US State Department
Chapter 2. Country Reports: Middle East and North Africa Overview - 2015: http://www.state.gov/j/ct/rls/crt/2015/257517.htm
- In 2015, Iran’s state sponsorship of terrorism worldwide remained undiminished through the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps-Qods Force (IRGC-QF), its Ministry of Intelligence and Security, and Tehran’s ally Hizballah, which remained a significant threat to the stability of Lebanon and the broader region. 

Chapter 3: State Sponsors of Terrorism Overview: http://www.state.gov/j/ct/rls/crt/2015/257520.htm
- IRAN
Designated as a State Sponsor of Terrorism in 1984, Iran continued its terrorist-related activity in 2015, including support for Hizballah, Palestinian terrorist groups in Gaza, and various groups in Iraq and throughout the Middle East. In 2015, Iran increased its assistance to Iraqi Shia terrorist groups, including Kata’ib Hizballah (KH), which is a U.S. designated Foreign Terrorist Organization, as part of an effort to fight the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) in Iraq and bolster the Asad regime in Syria. Iran used the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps-Qods Force (IRGC-QF) to implement foreign policy goals, provide cover for intelligence operations, and create instability in the Middle East. The IRGC-QF is Iran’s primary mechanism for cultivating and supporting terrorists abroad.

Author Martinez (2016) states that:
Iranian fast boats have once again harassed an American ship in the Persian Gulf, forcing a U.S. Navy patrol boat to take evasive maneuvers to avoid a collision with one of the Iranian boats. 
American officials have labeled the Iranian actions in Sunday's encounter involving the USS Firebolt as "unsafe and unprofessional." It is the latest in a string of such incidents over the past two weeks in which small craft from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy (IRGCN) have harassed U.S. Navy ships in the Gulf. 
"The USS Firebolt, a patrol craft, was operating in international waters in the central Arabian Gulf, was approached by seven fast-attack craft from Iran," Capt. Jeff Davis, a Pentagon spokesman, told reporters today. (¶ 1-3).
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Stuster (2016) States that:
he State Department released its annual report on terrorism yesterday. As in previous years, Iran was identified as the leading state sponsor of terrorism on account of its support for designated terrorist groups and proxy militias in Lebanon, Syria, and Iraq; the report also notes that Iran has been implicated in investigations of armed Shia political dissidents in Bahrain. Syria and Sudan were also listed as state sponsors of terrorism. The report states that the Islamic State is a larger threat than al-Qaeda, but that its recruitment and territory in Iraq and Syria have been significantly diminished since 2014. Despite these setbacks, the report notes that the group has expanded its number of affiliates and gained territory in Libya last year (¶ 1).

The IRGC’s elite Quds (Jerusalem) Force has cultivated, trained, armed, and supported numerous proxies, particularly the Lebanon-based Hizbullah; Iraqi Shia militant groups; Palestinian groups such as Hamas and Palestine Islamic Jihad; and groups that have fought against the governments of Afghanistan, Bahrain, Egypt, Israel, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, and Yemen.

IRGC general to head IR armed forces:
Stratfor, July 8, 'A New Military Chief Rises in Iran': https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/new-military-chief-rises-iran
Clips from the Stratfor article:
'Bogged down in regional conflicts and faced with renewed militancy at home, Iran is looking to shore up its military strength. To that end, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has placed an Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) commander at the head of the country's complex military establishment. Maj. Gen. Mohammad Hossein Bagheri took office as the new chief of the Armed Forces General Staff on July 5, marking the first time that the IRGC's leader has filled the position. Because the IRGC is widely perceived to be the best-equipped and best-trained branch of the Iranian military, the country's leaders may be hoping to bring the rest of the defense forces up to speed by having them follow the IRGC's example.
But another motive could be behind the promotion. Iran's economy is opening up as a result of the country's recent nuclear deal with the West, and some of Iran's most powerful stakeholders — the IRGC included — could see their strength erode because of it. Granting the military organization control over other politicized institutions, such as the armed forces, may be Khamenei's way of ensuring the IRGC's continued influence and, in doing so, protecting his control over one of Iran's most formidable groups.'
See also my earlier postings of [IRGC] Quds force Qasem Soleimani running ground ops in IQ.

In Havana in around 2001 (legally, since you asked, on a educational-programme ticket from OFAC),  wandered into the Plaza de San Francisco de Asis.   There was a Benetton shop there.  The hotel business was locked up by Canadians and Italians, and other global firms had offices or shops around town and throughout the country.  This was a result of the dazzingly successful five-decade run of the US trade blockade: Everybody else could do business there--although between the US attitude and the Cuban one, it wasn't easy--and in the meantime it gave the regime an excellent excuse for things not getting better.

This is nearly implausible, Iran has been on the list since 1984 and will most probably not be coming off the list this year or anytime soon. There is a recent historical example of what can happen when a country is taken off the list prematurely. N. Korea was taken off the list in 2008 as part of a bargaining chip in a nuclear agreement and once they were delisted proceeded to back out of their agreements, for instance, they began to limit IAEA inspections. However, the most likely reason it will not be taken off the list is this is an election year and making such a bold move, even if it were warranted, would be political suicide especially in an environment as contentious as the current one.

There was so much blowback over the elimination of the nuclear related sanctions that I would find it unlikely that Obama would burn more of his already limited political capital in Congress on this issue, and almost certainly not if he is still fighting to get a Supreme Court justice confirmed. Furthermore, the Iranians have still been fairly hostile (eg capturing the Navy sailors) and, perhaps most importantly, ARE state sponsors of terrorism. However, this could be used as a bargaining chip, for example to get Iran to the table in an anti-ISIS coalition with Saudi Arabia (though since Iran is already ideologically opposed to ISIS, the Saudis are more likely to need the prodding) or to get the Iranians to support some other Middle Eastern initiative.

I am still inclined to expect Obama to do this, both because it needs to be done and because Clinton can violently oppose it without causing any actual policy change--she needs a couple of issues to separate herself from him.  Once she's in office, she needn't do anything to reverse it unless she really wants to.

Middle eastern waters are still far too murky to foresee a public thawing of relations. But I'm pretty sure that at least some level of discussion will be taking place about some sort of quid pro quo. Perhaps Iran might step in to encourage Shias to make peace in other neighbouring nations in return for further concessions. Perhaps this has already happened to some extent with the nuclear deal, of course...
Hard to imagine scenario where U.S. Govt determines Iran is no longer a state sponsor of terror given the facts of the case, and the timing in an election year. Affirming forecast
